titlestmt.titleproper: United Mine Workers of America, Legal Department records, 1909-1982 09425
titlestmt.author: Barry Kernfeld

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2022-05-27 15:22:46 -0400.

did.unittitle: United Mine Workers of America, Legal Department records
did.abstract: This collection includes correspondence and court records on cases concerning the union. There are also files on legislative matters prior to 1940.
The United Mine Workers of America formed in 1890. The union established a Legal Department in the mid-1920s.
did.physloc: For current information on the location of these materials, please consult the Penn State University Libraries catalog via the link above. Archival collections may be housed in offsite storage. For materials stored offsite, please allow 2-3 business days for retrieval.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Collection is open for research. Records less than 20 years old shall be made accessible only with the written permission of the designated representative of the donor.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged into the following series: 1: Office Files (1909-1982); 2: Appeals (1909-1980); 3: Boyle and Yablonski (1933-1981); 4: Photographs (1973).

bioghist.head: Biographical or Historical Note
bioghist.p: The United Mine Workers of America (UMW) formed in 1890. From the early 1900s until his death in 1939, Judge Henry Warrum served as the organization's general counsel, handling litigation, but also advising on legal aspects of legislative matters that would have an impact on the union. John L. Lewis formed Labor's Non-Partisan League in 1936, in his dual capacity as president of both the UMW and the Congress of Industrial Organizations (CIO). The initial purpose of the League was to support the re-election of Franklin D. Roosevelt, but it took on a broad legislative agenda, and after 1939, advice on legislative matters pertaining to the UMW transferred from the general counsel to the League (see the UMW President's Office Records).

The exact date of formation of the UMW Legal Department is unknown. Earl E. Houck became an attorney for the UMW in July 1920. By 1926, UMW documents identify him as director of the Legal Department. In mid-1961, the union appointed Harrison Combs as assistant director, to assist Houck, who reduced his duties. Houck retained his position until his death in 1968, after which, in his honor, the UMW permanently removed the title of director of the Legal Department from its office structure. Combs continued as general counsel of the UMW until at least 1981. The Legal Department and a UMW general counsel continue to operate in the twenty-first century.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: This collection includes correspondence and court records on cases concerning the United Mine Workers of America (UMW). There are also files on legislative matters prior to 1940.

Series 1: Offices Files includes transcripts and correspondence from trials involving the UMW and from internal hearings, 1909-1931; documents on union legal and legislative matters sent to the attention of Legal Department director Earl Houck or UMW general counsel Henry Warrum prior to Warrum's death in 1939; summaries of closed cases, 1941-1960; detailed analysis and interpretations of articles of the UMW constitution, 1941-1982; and Legal Department correspondence, subject files, and reports from the decade immediately following the internal reorganization of the UMW in 1972.
Series 2: Appeals consists of records of U.S. Circuit Court and Supreme Court appeals of cases involving the UMW, or pertaining to legal questions of special interest to the UMW, from 1909 to 1980.

Series 3: Boyle and Yablonski holds copies of documents from a constellation of related criminal and civil cases from 1969-1978. These cases involved, in overlapping ways, the murders of UMW president William A. Boyle's rival Joseph Yablonski and his wife and daughter shortly after the 1969 UMW election; challenges to that 1969 election and investigations into the prior union election of 1964, through actions initiated by Willie Blankenship, Michael Trbovich, and the Miners for Democracy; allegations of financial misdeeds in the handling of UMW health, welfare, and retirement funds; and additional related criminal and civil actions involving other individuals, including James D. Hodgson, Edward Monborne, Albert Pass, and Richard Weaver. The most significant of these cases was Blankenship v. Boyle, the ruling in which ultimately enhanced the democratic process in the selection of union leadership and reformed the union pension fund. A further set of cases concerned assertions by Trbovich of continuing financial mismanagement by Boyle's successor, Arnold Miller.

These materials are entirely textual, except for three "I'm Loyal to Boyle" buttons from the 1969 election and copies of two photographs of Pass, a defendant in the Yablonski murders, from 1973. The textual records are roughly equally weighted between photocopies and original documents. Some items were obviously collected or copied for the purpose of legal discovery, exhibits, and analysis, or to capture news coverage of the constellation of Boyle and Yablonski cases, including extensive retrospective coverage in a Philadelphia Bulletin multi-part news series of 1981. A substantial number of the original documents situated within the series clearly originated in the UMW President's Office or Secretary-Treasurer's Office and were evidently carried into the Legal Department in the course of responses to the demands of the cases. No attempt has been made to repatriate these items; they remain situated within this Boyle and Yablonski series. Because of this relocation of documents and other vagaries involving the inclusion or association of items, the original order of these documents is largely unknown.
Series 4: Photographs (2 items) consists of the original prints of the two photos of Pass. These have been transferred into cold storage for the purpose of preservation.

userestrict.head: Copyright Restrictions
userestrict.p: Copyright is retained by the creators of items in these papers, or their descendants, as stipulated by United States copyright law.

For those materials where the United Mine Workers of America hold copyright, the United Mine Workers of America have given and assigned to the Library all rights of copyright as may be found among the materials.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Item Title], United Mine Workers of America, Legal Department records, HCLA 9425, Special Collections Library, Pennsylvania State University.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: The Pennsylvania State University Special Collections Library houses several other collections from the United Mine Workers. Please consult the library for additional information.
